In view of the existing difficulties of railway transport and of handling supplies at docks, besides the pressure on cold storage space, it has been decided not to ask Mr. Hoover for the further export of 42,000 tons of frozen beef for June and 42,000 tons for August mentioned in last week's Report.Sir Guy Granet has been notified that recent shipments of Canadian frozen beef have caused serious complaint both as regards weight and quality and that boneless beef has shown imperfect preparation. He has also been informed that butter from the United States is giving dissatisfaction owing to poor quality.Sir Guy Granet has again been asked to endeavour to divert the main flow of foodstuffs from North America from Liverpool to London.Sir Guy Granet cables that the following are payments for each commodity made through the Allied Provisions Export Commission to March 30th : $Hams, bacon - .....101,193,152.80Lard - - - - - - - - " "1 13 731 957 06Lard, French Government - - - - -) ' 'Neutral lard ------- 1,211,305.55Oleooil - ...... 2,339,013.29Cotton seed oil - ..... 1,299,225.90Preserved corned beef, civilian - 1,861,121.46Preserved corned beef, military - 4,822,224.09Frozen meat.....- - 13,070,099.15Butter -------- 3,244,382.29Pork and beans, military - - - - - 265,939.29Dried fruit- ------- 32,447.50Condensed milk....... 1,122,255.29Cheese -------- 186,602.54Onion seed........ 28,091.76Whale oil -....... 16,947.32Total - - - - - 144,424,765.29For the Aveek ending May 11th Sir Guy Granet estimates the commitments of tonnage at 17,833 with a food value of 8,670,580 dollars.Bacon, Earns, and Lard. The measures for relieving the congestion at Liverpool suggested by the investigations made by Sir H. Stuart at Liverpool, are being carried out. Some cargoes are sent by rail in their entirety to London to be sorted and allotted here on arrival. The Railway Executive Committee have arranged for two trains to be sent daily. An endeavour is also being made to divert some ships from Hull to London.It is hoped that a new Order fixing maximum retail prices for half a dozen cuts will be made shortly, but as the cost of imported bacon has risen it is not likely that prices can be much reduced.Butter. A further purchase of 160 tons of butter has been made in the United States of America at 401- to 44 cents per lb., f.a.s. in New York. During the week ending 11th May, 2,319 tons of butter arrived from Australia, 2,531 tons from New Zealand, 436 tons from the United States of America, 235 tons from South Africa, 35 tons from India, 20 tons from France, and 327 tons from Denmark, making a total of 5,903 tons. On the same date the stocks in hand were 12,857 tons and the quantity still on passage 20,384 tons.A (33)5683-3 Pk 1 130 5/18 E & SA Cereals. An Order amending the Grain (Prices) Order, 1917, dated 6th May, 1918, cancels clause 9 of the Principal Order, the effect being that after May 15 the prices of home-grown wheat, rye, barley, and oats, whether sold for the purpose of seed or otherwise, must not exceed the maximum prices set ont in the Order, and also that grain bought before that date specifically for the purpose of seed may be used for any other lawful purpose.Cheese. Advice has been received of further shipments of 3,645 tons of cheese from New Zealand, 800 tons from Australia, and 24 tons of old season cheese (the last of the unshipped stock) from Canada.1,037 tons of cheese have arrived from the United States of America, and 2,611 tons from New Zealand ; in the former country there remain 7,245 tons of unshipped stock and there are 1,200 tons on the way ; in the latter country there are 25,073 tons in store and 10,532 tons are on the water.Dried Fruits. The Greek Currants (Maximum Prices) Order, 1918, dated 1st May, 1918, fixes a maximum price for any currants produced in Greece which have not at the date of the Order arrived in the United Kingdom.The Dried Fruits (Restriction) Order, has been revoked as from 1st May.Fresh Fruit.-The Gooseberries Order, 1918, dated 11th May, 1918, prohibits the picking of gooseberries for sale on or after May 13, and the sale of any gooseberries on or after May 14. The restrictions remain in force until June 1 as regards England and Wales, and June 10 as regards Scotland.The Beehive Section (Maximum Prices) Order, 1918, dated 10th May 1918, fixes the maximum prices of beehive sections. A large quantity of these sections has been imported from the United States by the Ministry of Food with a view to assisting the production of honey.Intoxicating Liquor. A return of bulk barrelage at present sent into and out of the different districts is being required from all brewers excepting home-brewing publicans. The Committee appointed by Lord Rhondda at the request of the President of the Board of Trade to effect economies in fuel and transport have advised that brewers be asked to formulate voluntary schemes for concentrating brewing in each district, and limiting the area within which beer may be delivered from any area.On Tuesday, May 14th, Mr. dynes received Sir George Younger, M.P., and Col. John Gretton, M.P., who stated that considerable apprehension is felt in the trade lest, if these restrictions become operative, free brewers may be unable, when normal conditions recur, to recover the trade which has taken much time, effort, and capital to establish. It was arranged that the Chancellor of the Exchequer and Mr. Clynes should receive a deputation on the subject.Meat. The number of coupons available for the purchase of butcher's meat has been reduced from three to two, but the value of the remaining two has been increased from 5d. to 6cL each. This hears heavily on the retail butcher whose already limited turnover is still further reduced ; this step is not necessitated by any falling off in meat supplies, which for the time of the year are abundant, but by the heavy supplies of bacon. .Live stock is coming forward more freely than had been anticipated and arrivals of frozen meat are so large that there is great difficulty in. finding storage space for the meat; it may therefore become necessary to permit the third coupon again to be used for meat or in some other way to increase consumption in order to prevent delay in the discharging of steamers now arriving from North America. If the ration were increased it could be maintained for a considerable time.The sale of frozen meat is restricted to some extent by its poor quality ; grave complaints are made of it, and the reluctance of both butchers and public to accept it accentuates the difficulties of the situation.Steps are being taken to obtain from all retailers accurate returns of purchases and sales of meat, and to check these returns against coupons. The inspection of retailer's premises is being improved in order to stop evasions of the Meat Rationing Order.Milk.-Major Astor has forwarded to Lord Rhondda the resolutions of the Sub-Committee on the Government control of the wholesale distribution of milk (which were printed in last week's Report) in a covering letter from which the following comments of the parent Committee are extracted : " We trust that the Government may now be prepared to give effect to the recommendations, made by us in February, to control the wholesale distribution of milk as a temporary war measure in view of the fuller information which we are now able to offer them as to the methods by which these recommendations may be carried out." On the evidence now before us we are not prepared to agree to the desirability of purchase recommended in paragraph 8 of the Report of the * Sub-Committee. We believe that before coming to any decision as to the desirability of such a step more evidence is required both with regard to the financial terms and to the practical needs and effects of purchasing the entire wholesale milk trade of the country; at the same time, however, we recommend that immediate steps be taken to determine the basis on which the interests concerned could be acquired should this be deemed advisable at any time by the Government."In our opinion the Government should also examine the possibility and advisability, and also the conditions of compensating the interests concerned for any damage done to them by control Avithout actually purchasing such interests."There is no direct connection between the control of the wholesale milk trade and the control of the United Dairies Combine. The former is an emergency war measure, which should be regarded as merely temporary. So far as the latter is concerned, war conditions enable the Government to effect by agreement, or failing agreement, by compulsion, what would in normal times require specific anti-trust legislation.Potatoes. An announcement has been made that farmers who are able to satisfy the Ministry of Food on and after May 15 that they are unable to find purchasers for their potatoes in lots of 4 tons or more at or above the base price then ruling will be entitled to receive payment for their potatoes from the Ministry of Food at the rate of 11. per ton. If potatoes are sold to dealers at a figure which is below 11. per ton, but not below the current base price, the seller can claim the difference from the Ministry of Food.Base prices for potatoes delivered on and after May 15 have been fixed as follows : England and Wales, 11. per ton (i.e., no subsidy will be payable in respect ofpotatoes grown in England and Wales). Scotland. Southern counties, 6L 10s.,, Midland counties, 6i.,, Northern counties, 51. 10s. Ireland. 51.Tea. A Conference has been held with officers of the Colonial Office, the Board of Trade Department of Import Restrictions, and a representative of the Nyasaland tea importers. It was decided that Nyasaland tea might be imported if tonnage were available.The first purchases, of China tea on behalf of the Ministry of Food have now been made and some shipments are'being effected.Organised Distribution.Local administration. The number of applications for sanction to increase the membership of the Food Control Committees, on behalf of labour women, and of the Co-operative Movement, are decreasing. In the past week only six applications were received, and authority was given to seven Committees to increase their numbers.On Monday, May 13, Mr. Clynes received a deputation from the Wallasley local authorities on the subject of the resignation of the local food committee and the difficulties which have occurred between the Committee and the Divisional Commis-sioner.. The discussion appeared to remove all misunderstanding and it is understood that a. fresh committee will be forthwith elected.Meat rationing. The Ministry of Food have issued revised instructions having immediate effect, regulating the sale of offal, and making other amendments in the Meat Rationing Scheme., , -Certain kinds of edible offal, horseflesh, meat of goats and kids, and certain meat pies, may be sold without coupons.In order to encourage the sale of non-exempted meats of all kinds the coupon values given in the Table of Equivalent Weights have been considerably increased.The Commissioner for the London. Division has drawn attention to a difficult problem with regard to West End butchers, arising out of the restrictions imposed on the sale of meat. Their position, and that of the butchers in the East End of London may, he says, be regarded as reversed since the War. To-day the East End butcher is, he points out, making good profits, while the trade in the West End is so greatly diminished that many of the butchers with shops in highly-rented localities are losing so heavily that they find themselves unable to meet their liabilities. At the same time these latter butchers are supplying a want as retail distributors to thickly populated areas in that part of London, and that being so, they contend that they should be subsidized by Government. The Commissioner suggests that they will have to combine and work out a basis for themselves, although this would entail the closing of a proportion of the shops concerned. Some solution of the difficulty appears to be required without delay.Supplementary Rations.- On Tuesday, May 14th, Mr. Clynes received a deputation from Manchester munition workers, on the subject of supplementary rations for women on heavy work.Certain modifications in the present system of dealing with applications for extra rations on the grounds of ill-health were submitted to Mr. Clynes on Tuesday, May 14th. Captain Tallents outlined the following fresh arrangements which had been suggested to him by Dr. Hutchison : (1) The schedule of diseases in respect of which Committees may grant extra rations without reference to London should now be extended. Dr. Hutchi-son had mentioned as instances of diseases of this kind : Duodenal ulcers.Graves disease (exophthalmic goitre). Pernicious anaemia. Asthma in old people.Failure to digest starch or bacon (generally in old people). Severe loss of blood (fats and meat). Nephritis (fat only).Dysentery, malaria, or shell-shock in the case of ex-soldiers, but not healed wounds.Convalescence from serious illness or operation, including child-birth, in which the child does not survive.Dr. Hutchison is prepared to consider this list carefully, and to suggest the period for which extra rations might be granted by the Food Control Committee concerned in each instance. Generally speaking it was thought that one month would be a reasonable time. He will also consider in each case whether the alternative of an extra meat or fat ration might be given. As soon as his list is complete he wishes to consult the Reference Committee of the Colleges of Physicians and Surgeons, with a representative of the Central Medical War Committee.(2) Every Food Control Committee should be authorised to grant on medical certificates extra rations in cases of - emergency for one week, pending confirmation in London.(3) Food Control Committees might be authorised to grant extra meat to make raw beef juice for babies below one year on a medical certificate, such a grant to be limited to a fortnight.(4) White flour applications should in future be dealt with in the first instance by Local Food Offices, who should be empowered to make a grant for a period not exceeding six weeks. Applications for renewal should be made probably through the Food Office to the Ministry of Food, and should contain full particulars of the reasons for the claim certified or given by the doctor in the case. Steps will be taken to bring to the notice of doctors the latest available information as to the cases in which grants should be made. In suitable cases of renewal a permit to obtain white flour for 12 months should be granted. This suggestion is subject to the approval of the Royal Commission on Wheat Supplies.(5) Maternity Centres providing meals for mothers should be allowed to serve meat without requiring the production of coupons.(6) Boys passing the age of 18 and preparing to take up military service at, e.g., 18 , should be empowered to get the supplementary card " C."(7) The proof instruction with regard to expectant mothers should at once be issued, the alternative being given between one meat coupon and one PART II. SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION.The progress recorded in the following paragraphs and tables confirms the views expressed in recent reports that May would witness a change in the food position : (1) The stocks (Table F) are generally satisfactory, as will be seen by their comparison with those held on May 1st, 1917, or in previous months of the current year. In two cases, however, their size is apt to be misleading. The stock of bacon and ham has increased, but, on the other hand, the substitution of bacon for meat on an additional coupon makes a large stock and heavy supplies essential. Again, the stock of sugar is unusually high. It must, however, be remembered that the sources of supply have been curtailed, and that when the Cuban imports are over there will be little to look forward to for some time. Unless we begin the winter with a large stock, and care be exercised in its conservation, a reduction in the ration may be necessary in the beginning of next year.(2) Rationing has undoubtedly proved successful in lessening the rate of consumption, despite the leakages which naturally have accompanied its inauguration in, at any rate, some districts. The increase in the ration has had several advantages. It has shown that a rationing system is elastic, and has done much to convince the public that the restrictions on consumption will be relaxed when circumstances and the considerations of future safety permit.(3) Contrary to anticipations, the rationing of certain foods has not been accompanied by a rise in the consumption of breadstuffs, which, as shown in Table E, has remained singularly steady for several months. No doubt the plentiful supply of potatoes has conduced to this result. ' A consider-able fall, such as that experienced during the summer in 1917, can.hardly be anticipated. ............. 1............................a 3whole fats ration per week. The form M. 55 as at present drafted, has to be further amended so far as the declaration to be made by the expectant mother herself is concerned.(8) The Department would consult the Local Government Board as to the best means of linking up the notification to tuberculosis patients with the grant of extra rations.(9) The Ministry of Food will consult the British Medical Association as to the form in which a check could best he made upon the improper grant of medical certificates by local doctors to the detriment of other doctors in their neighbourhood, who act according to the spirit of the Ministry of Foods intentions.Enforcement of Orders.A comparison of the recent returns show that in the past week the number of prosecutions have fallen off considerably, particularly in London, which only sent in 39 cases as against 180 in the previous week, but the Home Counties Division sent in nine more cases than the week before, heading the list of Divisional Returns with 78 prosecutions. In three Divisions Newcastle, Glasgow and Inverness-it is satisfactory to find, as showing the care exercised in bringing pi-osecutions, that the percentage of successful convictions was .100. The total number of prosecutions for the week was 617, 552 of which were successful. The average fine for England, Scotland and Wales was 8L 11s. id., for Ireland 6s., showing the increase in the former case of 31. 16s. lOd. and in the latter a decrease of 2s. It is remarked by the Commissioner for the North Wales Division that there is a reluctance on the part of the Food Committees in that Division to take proceedings and that they are content with warning offenders only. Prosecutions were issued this week under 64 Orders six more than in the previous week.The largest number of returns amounting to 82 wras in connection with the Potatoes (Growers Returns) Order. There was a marked decrease in cases in con-nection with the Public Meals Order, there being only nine this week against 40 the week before. j :: . Imports.The imports of food in the week ended March .11th were considerably above the relatively high average of the past four weeks. The total quantity of the principal foods and feeding stuffs received, as shown in Table A, amounted to 291,800 tons compared with 253,800 tons in the preceding week. Arrivals of wheat and wheaten flour were again at a high level and amounted to 124,200 tons, compared with an average of 68,700 tons since the beginning of the year. Converted into equivalent grain the increase on the week before was 32,000 tons. Other cereals more than recovered their fall of last week. Both rice and maize arrived in large quantities. The average weekly aggregate of all cereals, including wheat, for the four weeks to May 11th was 184,100 tons, compared with 93,500 in the previous four weeks.From the exceptional figures of last week meat and bacon and hams declined heavily, the former from 20,100 tons to 12,300 tons, the latter from 38,100 tons to 18,300 tons. Only 18,700 tons of sugar were received, which is less than half the amount received a year ago. Cheese was much better than for several weeks past but slightly below the weekly average of 1917. More than 8,600 tons of tea were received as against 4,300 tons in the corresponding week of last year.Imports of oil seeds, nuts and kernels during April showed a great improvement on those of March, and on those a year ago. In the first four months of this year total arrivals have been 9 per cent, less than in the first four months of 1917.Consumption.Meat. For the week ended May 11th the aggregate supplies at the Central London Markets were 3,432 tons, a decline on the week before of 9 per cent. There were falls in both home and imported supplies, in the former of 124 tons and in the latter of 200 tons.: Total supplies at the four markets included in Table B were practically the same for the week ended May 4th, as for the week before. There was again an increase in home-fed meat and a decrease in foreign meat amounting to 200 tons for each kind. Heavier imports of meat are not having as sustained or as great an effect as desired on the marketed supplies of home-killed meat. For January of this year the percentage of foreign meat in the total at these four markets was 44, for February 51, for March 62, and for April 61, but for the week under review the percentage was only 54. A similar tale is told by the preliminary returns for April of the number of animals slaughtered (Table C). Except in pigs, where there is a further heavy decline, the figures show no marked changes on March. Compared with a year ago the number of cattle and sheep killed were each about 30 per cent, lower, but a month ago the corresponding falls were 35 per cent, and 39 per cent, respectively. From March to April 1917, the index fell 7-1- points for cattle and 7 points for sheep ; this year the fall in cattle was only 2 points and in sheep there was a rise of 1 point."Market returns show that the number of cattle stalled in England and Wales was 7 per cent, less in the week ended May 4th than in the preceding week. Figures now available point to an increase in stocks of wheat during April, this being the first month of the present cereal year during which stocks have risen. Maize and rice have also increased during the past month, but barley and oats have fallen. Stocks of wheat are much larger than a year ago.All other stocks, with the exception of coffee, cocoa, oilseed cake and margarine, rose during the month. Particularly marked was the increase in bacon and hams, from 9,300 tons to 30,100 tons. Stocks are, however, still 15,700 tons below last May. Other meats also rose and are all higher than a year ago.The stock of sugar has again substantially increased. The contrast with last year when the stock was only 18,000 tons, is striking; but, as pointed out in previous Reports, the apparent security in the sugar position is heavily discounted by the necessity of building up unusually large stocks by the autumn in order that adequate supplies for the winter may be assured, only very small imports can be expected when the Cuban crop is exhausted.a 4 Table A..--Imports" of Principal Food and Feeding Stuffs.Article.
